documents: Malays J Pathol 2021; 43(1): 41 48 ORIGINAL ARTICLE A national audit of estimated glomerular estimated glomerular filtration rate and proteinuria and the MACB chronic kidney disease Task Force recommendations Pavai STHANESHWAR1, Leslie Charles LAI2, Raja Elina RAJA AZZIDIN3, Baizurah MOHD. HUSSAIN4, Siti Sharina ANAS5, Sivasangkari SUPREMANIAM6, Low Yoke LEE7, Nafisah MOHAMAD NOOR8, Harmiza Bte HARUN8 1Department of Pathology, Faculty of Medicine, University Malaya; 2Gleneagles Hospital, Kuala Lumpur; 3Malaysian Association of Clinical Biochemists; 4Hospital Ampang; 5Department of Pathology, Hospital Putrajaya; 6Pathology Department, Women and Children Hospital, Kuala Lumpur; 7Pantai Premier Pathology Sdn Bhd, Kuala Lumpur; and 8Department of Pathology, Hospital Kuala Lumpur. Abstract Introduction: The Malaysian Association of Clinical Biochemists (MACB) established a Task Force for Chronic Kidney Disease. A survey was undertaken by the Task Force on the reporting of estimated glomerular estimated glomerular filtration rate (estimated glomerular filtration rate) and Urine albumin by hospital laboratories in Malaysia in both the government and private sectors. Materials and Methods: An e-mail invitation to participate in an online survey was sent to hospital laboratories in Malaysia (n140). Questions regarding methods for measuring Creatinine, equations for calculating estimated glomerular filtration rate, estimated glomerular filtration rate reporting, the terminology used in reporting Urine albumin, types of samples and the cut-off values used for normal albuminuria. Results: A total of 42/140 (30%) laboratories answered the questionnaire. The prevalent method used for serum Creatinine measurement was the Jaffé method (88. 1%) traceable to isotope-dilution mass spectrometry. estimated glomerular filtration rate was reported along with serum Creatinine by 61. 9% of laboratories while 33. 3% of laboratories report estimated glomerular filtration rate on request. The formula used for estimated glomerular filtration rate reporting was mainly MDRD (64. 3%) and results were reported as exact numbers even when the estimated glomerular filtration rate was 60 milliliters per minute/1. 73m2. The term microalbumin is still used by 83. 3% of laboratories. There is a large heterogeneity among the labs regarding the type of sample recommended for measuring Urine albumin, reference interval and reporting units. Conclusion: It is evident that the laboratory assessment of chronic Kidney disease in Malaysia is not standardised. It is essential to provide a national framework for standardised reporting of estimated glomerular filtration rate and Urine albumin. Recommendations developed by the MACB chronic kidney disease Task Force, if adopted by all laboratories, will lead to a reduction in this variability.
